Following World War III, all the nations of the world agreed to 50 years of strict isolation from one another in order to prevent additional conflicts. 50 years later, the United States comes out of exile, only to learn that no one else went into isolation. As it happened, the rest of the world had united, recovered from the conflicts of previous decades, and essentially erased all US influence. An era of peace and prosperity had emerged,  and without America constantly stirring the foreign policy pot, even the most malevolent dictatorships had become benevolent democracies.

Following World War III, all the nations of the world agreed to 50 years of strict isolation from one another in order to prevent additional conflicts. 50 years later, the United States comes out of exile, only to learn that no one else went into isolation. As it happened, the rest of the world had united, recovered from the conflicts of previous decades, and essentially erased all US influence. An era of peace and prosperity had emerged,  and without America constantly stirring the foreign policy pot, even the most malevolent dictatorships had become benevolent democracies.

An era of peace and prosperity had emerged,  and without America constantly stirring the foreign policy pot, even the most malevolent dictatorships had become benevolent democracies.

The planet was clean, global warming had been reversed, and even the poorest countries were developing like never before, in a manner that benefited both human prosperity, and the planet's ecosystems. Tremendous medical and technological advances had been made: there was a cure for every disease, and some steps had been taken towards manned space flight, terraforming, and eventual colonization of other planets in the solar system. In short,

An era of peace and prosperity had emerged,  and without America constantly stirring the foreign policy pot, even the most malevolent dictatorships had become benevolent democracies.

The planet was clean, global warming had been reversed, and even the poorest countries were developing like never before, in a manner that benefited both human prosperity, and the planet's ecosystems. Tremendous medical and technological advances had been made: there was a cure for every disease, and some steps had been taken towards manned space flight, terraforming, and eventual colonization of other planets in the solar system. In short, the world was a better place without the United States.

In short, the world was a better place without the United States.

Following World War III, all the nations of the world agreed to 50 years of strict isolation from one another in order to prevent additional conflicts. 50 years later, the United States comes out of exile, only to learn that no one else went into isolation. As it happened, the rest of the world had united, recovered from the conflicts of previous decades, and essentially erased all US influence. An era of peace and prosperity had emerged,  and without America constantly stirring the foreign policy pot, even the most malevolent dictatorships had become benevolent democracies.

The planet was clean, global warming had been reversed, and even the poorest countries were developing like never before, in a manner that benefited both human prosperity, and the planet's ecosystems. In short, the world was a better place without the United States.

An era of peace and prosperity had emerged,  and without America constantly stirring the foreign policy pot, even the most malevolent dictatorships had become benevolent democracies.

The planet was clean, global warming had been reversed, and even the poorest countries were developing like never before, in a manner that benefited both human prosperity, and the planet's ecosystems. Tremendous medical and technological advances had been made: there was a cure for every disease, and some steps had been taken towards manned space flight, terraforming, and eventual colonization of other planets in the solar system. In short, the world was a better place without the United States.

The United States government sized up this situation, and an internal debate began; some suggested that the only way to reclaim its former glory would be for America to force its way back to the front of the world stage, while others suggested that perhaps the isolation of 50 years had contributed to a kind of peaceful stability, and that maybe the United States should leave well enough alone, and join in the peace and prosperity, in a more minor role rather than its former status as a superpower. An era of peace and prosperity had emerged,  and without America constantly stirring the foreign policy pot, even the most malevolent dictatorships had become benevolent democracies.

The planet was clean, global warming had been reversed, and even the poorest countries were developing like never before, in a manner that benefited both human prosperity, and the planet's ecosystems. Tremendous medical and technological advances had been made: there was a cure for every disease, and some steps had been taken towards manned space flight, terraforming, and eventual colonization of other planets in the solar system. In short, the world was a better place without the United States.

The United States government sized up this situation, and an internal debate began; some suggested that the only way to reclaim its former glory would be for America to force its way back to the front of the world stage, while others suggested that perhaps the isolation of 50 years had contributed to a kind of peaceful stability, and that maybe the United States should leave well enough alone, and join in the peace and prosperity, in a more minor role rather than its former status as a superpower. An era of peace and prosperity had emerged,  and without America constantly stirring the foreign policy pot, even the most malevolent dictatorships had become benevolent democracies.

The planet was clean, global warming had been reversed, and even the poorest countries were developing like never before, in a manner that benefited both human prosperity, and the planet's ecosystems. Tremendous medical and technological advances had been made: there was a cure for every disease, and some steps had been taken towards manned space flight, terraforming, and eventual colonization of other planets in the solar system. In short, the world was a better place without the United States.

The United States government sized up this situation, and an internal debate began; some suggested that the only way to reclaim its former glory would be for America to force its way back to the front of the world stage, while others suggested that perhaps the isolation of 50 years had contributed to a kind of peaceful stability, and that maybe the United States should leave well enough alone, and join in the peace and prosperity, in a more minor role rather than its former status as a superpower. A third group believed the current global situation was a lie, and that Americ

As it happened, the rest of the world had united, recovered from the conflicts of previous decades, and essentially erased all US influence. An era of peace and prosperity had emerged,  and without America constantly stirring the foreign policy pot, even the most malevolent dictatorships had become benevolent democracies.

The planet was clean, global warming had been reversed, and even the poorest countries were developing like never before, in a manner that benefited both human prosperity, and the planet's ecosystems. Tremendous medical and technological advances had been made: there was a cure for every disease, and some steps had been taken towards manned space flight, terraforming, and eventual colonization of other planets in the solar system. In short, the world was a better place without the United States.

The United States government sized up this situation, and an internal debate began; some suggested that the only way to reclaim its former glory would be for America to force its way back to the front of the world stage, while others suggested that perhaps the isolation of 50 years had contributed to a kind of peaceful stability, and that maybe the United States should leave well enough alone, and join in the peace and prosperity, in a more minor role rather than its former status as a superpower. A third group believed the current global situation was a house of c

An era of peace and prosperity had emerged,  and without America constantly stirring the foreign policy pot, even the most malevolent dictatorships had become benevolent democracies.

The planet was clean, global warming had been reversed, and even the poorest countries were developing like never before, in a manner that benefited both human prosperity, and the planet's ecosystems. Tremendous medical and technological advances had been made: there was a cure for every disease, and some steps had been taken towards manned space flight, terraforming, and eventual colonization of other planets in the solar system. In short, the world was a better place without the United States.

The United States government sized up this situation, and an internal debate began; some suggested that the only way to reclaim its former glory would be for America to force its way back to the front of the world stage, while others suggested that perhaps the isolation of 50 years had contributed to a kind of peaceful stability, and that maybe the United States should leave well enough alone, and join in the peace and prosperity, in a more minor role rather than its former status as a superpower. A third group believed the current global situation was a house of cards that would eventually collapse, and that the US could be best served by remaining in sitting out the collapse.

Tremendous medical and technological advances had been made: there was a cure for every disease, and some steps had been taken towards manned space flight, terraforming, and eventual colonization of other planets in the solar system. In short, the world was a better place without the United States.

The United States government sized up this situation, and an internal debate began; some suggested that the only way to reclaim its former glory would be for America to force its way back to the front of the world stage, while others suggested that perhaps the isolation of 50 years had contributed to a kind of peaceful stability, and that maybe the United States should leave well enough alone, and join in the peace and prosperity, in a more minor role rather than its former status as a superpower. A third group believed the current global situation was a house of cards that would eventually collapse, and that the US could be best served by remaining in isolation and sitting out the collapse.

An era of peace and prosperity had emerged,  and without America constantly stirring the foreign policy pot, even the most malevolent dictatorships had become benevolent democracies.

The planet was clean, global warming had been reversed, and even the poorest countries were developing like never before, in a manner that benefited both human prosperity, and the planet's ecosystems. Tremendous medical and technological advances had been made: there was a cure for every disease, and some steps had been taken towards manned space flight, terraforming, and eventual colonization of other planets in the solar system. In short, the world was a better place without the United States.

The United States government sized up this situation, and an internal debate began; some suggested that the only way to reclaim its former glory would be for America to force its way back to the front of the world stage, while others suggested that perhaps the isolation of 50 years had contributed to a kind of peaceful stability, and that maybe the United States should leave well enough alone, and join in the peace and prosperity, in a more minor role rather than its former status as a superpower. A third group believed the current global situation was a house of cards that would eventually collapse, and that the US could be best served by remaining in isolation and sitting out the collapse.

An era of peace and prosperity had emerged,  and without America constantly stirring the foreign policy pot, even the most malevolent dictatorships had become benevolent democracies.

The planet was clean, global warming had been reversed, and even the poorest countries were developing like never before, in a manner that benefited both human prosperity, and the planet's ecosystems. Tremendous medical and technological advances had been made: there was a cure for every disease, and some steps had been taken towards manned space flight, terraforming, and eventual colonization of other planets in the solar system. In short, the world was a better place without the United States.

The United States government sized up this situation, and an internal debate began; some suggested that the only way to reclaim its former glory would be for America to force its way back to the front of the world stage, while others suggested that perhaps the isolation of 50 years had contributed to a kind of peaceful stability, and that maybe the United States should leave well enough alone, and join in the peace and prosperity, in a more minor role rather than its former status as a superpower. A third group believed the current global situation was a house of cards that would eventually collapse, and that the US could be best served by remaining in isolation and sitting out the collapse.

An era of peace and prosperity had emerged,  and without America constantly stirring the foreign policy pot, even the most malevolent dictatorships had become benevolent democracies.

The planet was clean, global warming had been reversed, and even the poorest countries were developing like never before, in a manner that benefited both human prosperity, and the planet's ecosystems. Tremendous medical and technological advances had been made: there was a cure for every disease, and some steps had been taken towards manned space flight, terraforming, and eventual colonization of other planets in the solar system. In short, the world was a better place without the United States.

The United States government sized up this situation, and an internal debate began; some suggested that the only way to reclaim its former glory would be for America to force its way back to the front of the world stage, while others suggested that perhaps the isolation of 50 years had contributed to a kind of peaceful stability, and that maybe the United States should leave well enough alone, and join in the peace and prosperity, in a more minor role rather than its former status as a superpower. A third group believed the current global situation was a house of cards that would eventually collapse, and that the US could be best served by remaining in isolation and sitting out the collapse.

The U.S. moved to re-establish diplomatic ties with the world's nations, but internally, the debate over America's futu

Following World War III, all the nations of the world agreed to 50 years of strict isolation from one another in order to prevent additional conflicts. 50 years later, the United States comes out of exile, only to learn that no one else went into isolation. As it happened, the rest of the world had united, recovered from the conflicts of previous decades, and essentially erased all US influence. An era of peace and prosperity had emerged,  and without America constantly stirring the foreign policy pot, even the most malevolent dictatorships had become benevolent democracies.

The planet was clean, global warming had been reversed, and even the poorest countries were developing like never before, in a manner that benefited both human prosperity, and the planet's ecosystems. Tremendous medical and technological advances had been made: there was a cure for every disease, and some steps had been taken towards manned space flight, terraforming, and eventual colonization of other planets in the solar system. In short, the world was a better place without the United States.

The United States government sized up this situation, and an internal debate began; some suggested that the only way to reclaim its former glory would be for America to force its way back to the front of the world stage, while others suggested that perhaps the isolation of 50 years had contributed to a kind of peaceful stability, and that maybe the United States should leave well enough alone, and join in the peace and prosperity, in a more minor role rather than its former status as a superpower. A third group believed the current global situation was a house of cards that would eventually collapse, and that the US could be best served by remaining in isolation and sitting out the collapse.

As it happened, the rest of the world had united, recovered from the conflicts of previous decades, and essentially erased all US influence. An era of peace and prosperity had emerged,  and without America constantly stirring the foreign policy pot, even the most malevolent dictatorships had become benevolent democracies.

The planet was clean, global warming had been reversed, and even the poorest countries were developing like never before, in a manner that benefited both human prosperity, and the planet's ecosystems. Tremendous medical and technological advances had been made: there was a cure for every disease, and some steps had been taken towards manned space flight, terraforming, and eventual colonization of other planets in the solar system. In short, the world was a better place without the United States.

The United States government sized up this situation, and an internal debate began; some suggested that the only way to reclaim its former glory would be for America to force its way back to the front of the world stage, while others suggested that perhaps the isolation of 50 years had contributed to a kind of peaceful stability, and that maybe the United States should leave well enough alone, and join in the peace and prosperity, in a more minor role rather than its former status as a superpower. A third group believed the current global situation was a house of cards that would eventually collapse, and that the US could be best served by remaining in isolation and sitting out the collapse.

Following World War III, all the nations of the world agreed to 50 years of strict isolation from one another in order to prevent additional conflicts. 50 years later, the United States comes out of exile, only to learn that no one else went into isolation. As it happened, the rest of the world had united, recovered from the conflicts of previous decades, and essentially erased all US influence. An era of peace and prosperity had emerged,  and without America constantly stirring the foreign policy pot, even the most malevolent dictatorships had become benevolent democracies.

The planet was clean, global warming had been reversed, and even the poorest countries were developing like never before, in a manner that benefited both human prosperity, and the planet's ecosystems. Tremendous medical and technological advances had been made: there was a cure for every disease, and some steps had been taken towards manned space flight, terraforming, and eventual colonization of other planets in the solar system. In short, the world was a better place without the United States.

The United States government sized up this situation, and an internal debate began; some suggested that the only way to reclaim its former glory would be for America to force its way back to the front of the world stage, while others suggested that perhaps the isolation of 50 years had contributed to a kind of peaceful stability, and that maybe the United States should leave well enough alone, and join in the peace and prosperity, in a more minor role rather than its former status as a superpower. An era of peace and prosperity had emerged,  and without America constantly stirring the foreign policy pot, even the most malevolent dictatorships had become benevolent democracies.

The planet was clean, global warming had been reversed, and even the poorest countries were developing like never before, in a manner that benefited both human prosperity, and the planet's ecosystems. Tremendous medical and technological advances had been made: there was a cure for every disease, and some steps had been taken towards manned space flight, terraforming, and eventual colonization of other planets in the solar system. In short, the world was a better place without the United States.

The United States government sized up this situation, and an internal debate began; some suggested that the only way to reclaim its former glory would be for America to force its way back to the front of the world stage, while others suggested that perhaps the isolation of 50 years had contributed to a kind of peaceful stability, and that maybe the United States should leave well enough alone, and join in the peace and prosperity, in a more minor role rather than its former status as a superpower. A third group believed the current global situation was a house of cards that would eventually collapse, and that the US could be best served by remaining in isolation and sitting out the collapse.

The U.S. moved to re-establish diplomatic ties with the world's nations, but internally, the debate over America's future quickly escalated, and before serious steps could be made in diplomacy, America found itself in a full-scale civil war, with the expansion isolationist and diplomatic factions fighting for control of the United States.

An era of peace and prosperity had emerged,  and without America constantly stirring the foreign policy pot, even the most malevolent dictatorships had become benevolent democracies.

The planet was clean, global warming had been reversed, and even the poorest countries were developing like never before, in a manner that benefited both human prosperity, and the planet's ecosystems. Tremendous medical and technological advances had been made: there was a cure for every disease, and some steps had been taken towards manned space flight, terraforming, and eventual colonization of other planets in the solar system. In short, the world was a better place without the United States.

The United States government sized up this situation, and an internal debate began; some suggested that the only way to reclaim its former glory would be for America to force its way back to the front of the world stage, while others suggested that perhaps the isolation of 50 years had contributed to a kind of peaceful stability, and that maybe the United States should leave well enough alone, and join in the peace and prosperity, in a more minor role rather than its former status as a superpower. A third group believed the current global situation was a house of cards that would eventually collapse, and that the US could be best served by remaining in isolation and sitting out the collapse.

The U.S. moved to re-establish diplomatic ties with the world's nations, but internally, the debate over America's future quickly escalated, and before serious steps could be made in diplomacy, America found itself in a full-scale civil war, with the expansionist, isolationist, and diplomatic factions fighting for control of the United States. The world observed the US civil war with varying degrees of concern, but ultimately took no action to interfere.

As it happened, the rest of the world had united, recovered from the conflicts of previous decades, and essentially erased all US influence. An era of peace and prosperity had emerged,  and without America constantly stirring the foreign policy pot, even the most malevolent dictatorships had become benevolent democracies.

The planet was clean, global warming had been reversed, and even the poorest countries were developing like never before, in a manner that benefited both human prosperity, and the planet's ecosystems. Tremendous medical and technological advances had been made: there was a cure for every disease, and some steps had been taken towards manned space flight, terraforming, and eventual colonization of other planets in the solar system. In short, the world was a better place without the United States.

The United States government sized up this situation, and an internal debate began; some suggested that the only way to reclaim its former glory would be for America to force its way back to the front of the world stage, while others suggested that perhaps the isolation of 50 years had contributed to a kind of peaceful stability, and that maybe the United States should leave well enough alone, and join in the peace and prosperity, in a more minor role rather than its former status as a superpower. A third group believed the current global situation was a house of cards that would eventually collapse, and that the US could be best served by remaining in isolation and sitting out the collapse.

The U.S. moved to re-establish diplomatic ties with the world's nations, but internally, the debate over America's future quickly escalated, and before serious steps could be made in diplomacy, America found itself in a full-scale civil war, with the expansionist, isolationist, and diplomatic factions fighting for control of the United States. The U.S. moved to re-establish diplomatic ties with the world's nations, but internally, the debate over America's future quickly escalated, and before serious steps could be made in diplomacy, America found itself in a full-scale civil war, with the expansionist, isolationist, and diplomatic factions fighting for control of the United States. The world observed the US civil war with varying degrees of concern, but ultimately took no action to interfere. They felt that the world was fine without America, and

Following World War III, all the nations of the world agreed to 50 years of strict isolation from one another in order to prevent additional conflicts. 50 years later, the United States comes out of exile, only to learn that no one else went into isolation. As it happened, the rest of the world had united, recovered from the conflicts of previous decades, and essentially erased all US influence. An era of peace and prosperity had emerged,  and without America constantly stirring the foreign policy pot, even the most malevolent dictatorships had become benevolent democracies.

The planet was clean, global warming had been reversed, and even the poorest countries were developing like never before, in a manner that benefited both human prosperity, and the planet's ecosystems. Tremendous medical and technological advances had been made: there was a cure for every disease, and some steps had been taken towards manned space flight, terraforming, and eventual colonization of other planets in the solar system. In short, the world was a better place without the United States.

Following World War III, all the nations of the world agreed to 50 years of strict isolation from one another in order to prevent additional conflicts. 50 years later, the United States comes out of exile, only to learn that no one else went into isolation. As it happened, the rest of the world had united, recovered from the conflicts of previous decades, and essentially erased all US influence. An era of peace and prosperity had emerged,  and without America constantly stirring the foreign policy pot, even the most malevolent dictatorships had become benevolent democracies.

The planet was clean, global warming had been reversed, and even the poorest countries were developing like never before, in a manner that benefited both human prosperity, and the planet's ecosystems. Tremendous medical and technological advances had been made: there was a cure for every disease, and some steps had been taken towards manned space flight, terraforming, and eventual colonization of other planets in the solar system. In short, the world was a better place without the United States.

Following World War III, all the nations of the world agreed to 50 years of strict isolation from one another in order to prevent additional conflicts. 50 years later, the United States comes out of exile, only to learn that no one else went into isolation. As it happened, the rest of the world had united, recovered from the conflicts of previous decades, and essentially erased all US influence. An era of peace and prosperity had emerged,  and without America constantly stirring the foreign policy pot, even the most malevolent dictatorships had become benevolent democracies.

The planet was clean, global warming had been reversed, and even the poorest countries were developing like never before, in a manner that benefited both human prosperity, and the planet's ecosystems. Tremendous medical and technological advances had been made: there was a cure for every disease, and some steps had been taken towards manned space flight, terraforming, and eventual colonization of other planets in the solar system. In short, the world was a better place without the United States.

The United States government sized up this situation, and an internal debate began; some suggested that the only way to reclaim its former glory would be for America to force its way back to the front of the world stage, while others suggested that perhaps the isolation of 50 years had contributed to a kind of peaceful stability, and that maybe the United States should leave well enough alone, and join in the peace and prosperity, in a more minor role rather than its former status as a superpower. A third group believed the current global situation was a house of cards that would eventually collapse, and that the US could be best served by remaining in isolation and sitting out the collapse.

Following World War III, all the nations of the world agreed to 50 years of strict isolation from one another in order to prevent additional conflicts. 50 years later, the United States comes out of exile, only to learn that no one else went into isolation. As it happened, the rest of the world had united, recovered from the conflicts of previous decades, and essentially erased all US influence. An era of peace and prosperity had emerged,  and without America constantly stirring the foreign policy pot, even the most malevolent dictatorships had become benevolent democracies.

The planet was clean, global warming had been reversed, and even the poorest countries were developing like never before, in a manner that benefited both human prosperity, and the planet's ecosystems. Tremendous medical and technological advances had been made: there was a cure for every disease, and some steps had been taken towards manned space flight, terraforming, and eventual colonization of other planets in the solar system. In short, the world was a better place without the United States.

The United States government sized up this situation, and an internal debate began; some suggested that the only way to reclaim its former glory would be for America to force its way back to the front of the world stage, while others suggested that perhaps the isolation of 50 years had contributed to a kind of peaceful stability, and that maybe the United States should leave well enough alone, and join in the peace and prosperity, in a more minor role rather than its former status as a superpower. A third group believed the current global situation was a house of cards that would eventually collapse, and that the US could be best served by remaining in isolation and sitting out the collapse.

The U.S. moved to re-establish diplomatic ties with the world's nations, but internally, the debate over America's future quickly escalated, and before serious steps could be made in diplomacy, America found itself in a full-scale civil war, with the expansionist, isolationist, and diplomatic factions fighting for control of the United States. The world observed the US civil war with varying degrees of concern, but ultimately took no action to interfere. They felt that the world was fine without America, and what happened there was of no concern to the global community.

As it happened, the rest of the world had united, recovered from the conflicts of previous decades, and essentially erased all US influence. An era of peace and prosperity had emerged,  and without America constantly stirring the foreign policy pot, even the most malevolent dictatorships had become benevolent democracies.

The planet was clean, global warming had been reversed, and even the poorest countries were developing like never before, in a manner that benefited both human prosperity, and the planet's ecosystems. Tremendous medical and technological advances had been made: there was a cure for every disease, and some steps had been taken towards manned space flight, terraforming, and eventual colonization of other planets in the solar system. In short, the world was a better place without the United States.

The United States government sized up this situation, and an internal debate began; some suggested that the only way to reclaim its former glory would be for America to force its way back to the front of the world stage, while others suggested that perhaps the isolation of 50 years had contributed to a kind of peaceful stability, and that maybe the United States should leave well enough alone, and join in the peace and prosperity, in a more minor role rather than its former status as a superpower. A third group believed the current global situation was a house of cards that would eventually collapse, and that the US could be best served by remaining in isolation and sitting out the collapse.

The U.S. moved to re-establish diplomatic ties with the world's nations, but internally, the debate over America's future quickly escalated, and before serious steps could be made in diplomacy, America found itself in a full-scale civil war, with the expansionist, isolationist, and diplomatic factions fighting for control of the United States. The world observed the US civil war with varying degrees of concern, but ultimately took no action to interfere. They felt that the world was fine without America, and what happened there was of no concern to the global community.

An era of peace and prosperity had emerged,  and without America constantly stirring the foreign policy pot, even the most malevolent dictatorships had become benevolent democracies.

The planet was clean, global warming had been reversed, and even the poorest countries were developing like never before, in a manner that benefited both human prosperity, and the planet's ecosystems. Tremendous medical and technological advances had been made: there was a cure for every disease, and some steps had been taken towards manned space flight, terraforming, and eventual colonization of other planets in the solar system. In short, the world was a better place without the United States.

The United States government sized up this situation, and an internal debate began; some suggested that the only way to reclaim its former glory would be for America to force its way back to the front of the world stage, while others suggested that perhaps the isolation of 50 years had contributed to a kind of peaceful stability, and that maybe the United States should leave well enough alone, and join in the peace and prosperity, in a more minor role rather than its former status as a superpower. A third group believed the current global situation was a house of cards that would eventually collapse, and that the US could be best served by remaining in isolation and sitting out the collapse.

The U.S. moved to re-establish diplomatic ties with the world's nations, but internally, the debate over America's future quickly escalated, and before serious steps could be made in diplomacy, America found itself in a full-scale civil war, with the expansionist, isolationist, and diplomatic factions fighting for control of the United States. The world observed the US civil war with varying degrees of concern, but ultimately took no action to interfere. They felt that the world was fine without America, and what happened there was of no concern to the global community.

Following World War III, all the nations of the world agreed to 50 years of strict isolation from one another in order to prevent additional conflicts. 50 years later, the United States comes out of exile, only to learn that no one else went into isolation. As it happened, the rest of the world had united, recovered from the conflicts of previous decades, and essentially erased all US influence. An era of peace and prosperity had emerged,  and without America constantly stirring the foreign policy pot, even the most malevolent dictatorships had become benevolent democracies.

The planet was clean, global warming had been reversed, and even the poorest countries were developing like never before, in a manner that benefited both human prosperity, and the planet's ecosystems. Tremendous medical and technological advances had been made: there was a cure for every disease, and some steps had been taken towards manned space flight, terraforming, and eventual colonization of other planets in the solar system. In short, the world was a better place without the United States.

The United States government sized up this situation, and an internal debate began; some suggested that the only way to reclaim its former glory would be for America to force its way back to the front of the world stage, while others suggested that perhaps the isolation of 50 years had contributed to a kind of peaceful stability, and that maybe the United States should leave well enough alone, and join in the peace and prosperity, in a more minor role rather than its former status as a superpower. A third group believed the current global situation was a house of cards that would eventually collapse, and that the US could be best served by remaining in isolation and sitting out the collapse.

The U.S. moved to re-establish diplomatic ties with the world's nations, but internally, the debate over America's future quickly escalated, and before serious steps could be made in diplomacy, America found itself in a full-scale civil war, with the expansionist, isolationist, and diplomatic factions fighting for control of the United States. The world observed the US civil war with varying degrees of concern, but ultimately took no action to interfere. They felt that the world was fine without America, and what happened there was of no concern to the global community.

Following World War III, all the nations of the world agreed to 50 years of strict isolation from one another in order to prevent additional conflicts. 50 years later, the United States comes out of exile, only to learn that no one else went into isolation. As it happened, the rest of the world had united, recovered from the conflicts of previous decades, and essentially erased all US influence. An era of peace and prosperity had emerged,  and without America constantly stirring the foreign policy pot, even the most malevolent dictatorships had become benevolent democracies.

The planet was clean, global warming had been reversed, and even the poorest countries were developing like never before, in a manner that benefited both human prosperity, and the planet's ecosystems. Tremendous medical and technological advances had been made: there was a cure for every disease, and some steps had been taken towards manned space flight, terraforming, and eventual colonization of other planets in the solar system. In short, the world was a better place without the United States.

The United States government sized up this situation, and an internal debate began; some suggested that the only way to reclaim its former glory would be for America to force its way back to the front of the world stage, while others suggested that perhaps the isolation of 50 years had contributed to a kind of peaceful stability, and that maybe the United States should leave well enough alone, and join in the peace and prosperity, in a more minor role rather than its former status as a superpower. A third group believed the current global situation was a house of cards that would eventually collapse, and that the US could be best served by remaining in isolation and sitting out the collapse.

The U.S. moved to re-establish diplomatic ties with the world's nations, but internally, the debate over America's future quickly escalated, and before serious steps could be made in diplomacy, America found itself in a full-scale civil war, with the expansionist, isolationist, and diplomatic factions fighting for control of the United States. The world observed the US civil war with varying degrees of concern, but ultimately took no action to interfere. They felt that the world was fine without America, and what happened there was of no concern to the global community.

This was a mistake. The Second Civil War raged out of control, eventually leading to the deployment of nuclear weapons, and the US became a nuclear wasteland. Far from being unaffected, the rest of the world suffered from the ensuing nuclear winter, and all the progress that humanity had made was swiftly erased.

The U.S. moved to re-establish diplomatic ties with the world's nations, but internally, the debate over America's future quickly escalated, and before serious steps could be made in diplomacy, America found itself in a full-scale civil war, with the expansionist, isolationist, and diplomatic factions fighting for control of the United States. The world observed the US civil war with varying degrees of concern, but ultimately took no action to interfere. They felt that the world was fine without America, and what happened there was of no concern to the global community.

This was a mistake. The Second Civil War raged out of control, eventually leading to the deployment of nuclear weapons, and the US became a nuclear wasteland. Far from being unaffected, the rest of the world suffered from the ensuing nuclear winter, and all the progress that humanity had made was swiftly erased.

Following World War III, all the nations of the world agreed to 50 years of strict isolation from one another in order to prevent additional conflicts. 50 years later, the United States comes out of exile, only to learn that no one else went into isolation. As it happened, the rest of the world had united, recovered from the conflicts of previous decades, and essentially erased all US influence. An era of peace and prosperity had emerged,  and without America constantly stirring the foreign policy pot, even the most malevolent dictatorships had become benevolent democracies.

The planet was clean, global warming had been reversed, and even the poorest countries were developing like never before, in a manner that benefited both human prosperity, and the planet's ecosystems. Tremendous medical and technological advances had been made: there was a cure for every disease, and some steps had been taken towards manned space flight, terraforming, and eventual colonization of other planets in the solar system. In short, the world was a better place without the United States.

Following World War III, all the nations of the world agreed to 50 years of strict isolation from one another in order to prevent additional conflicts. 50 years later, the United States comes out of exile, only to learn that no one else went into isolation. As it happened, the rest of the world had united, recovered from the conflicts of previous decades, and essentially erased all US influence. An era of peace and prosperity had emerged,  and without America constantly stirring the foreign policy pot, even the most malevolent dictatorships had become benevolent democracies.

The planet was clean, global warming had been reversed, and even the poorest countries were developing like never before, in a manner that benefited both human prosperity, and the planet's ecosystems. Tremendous medical and technological advances had been made: there was a cure for every disease, and some steps had been taken towards manned space flight, terraforming, and eventual colonization of other planets in the solar system. In short, the world was a better place without the United States.

The United States government sized up this situation, and an internal debate began; some suggested that the only way to reclaim its former glory would be for America to force its way back to the front of the world stage, while others suggested that perhaps the isolation of 50 years had contributed to a kind of peaceful stability, and that maybe the United States should leave well enough alone, and join in the peace and prosperity, in a more minor role rather than its former status as a superpower. A third group believed the current global situation was a house of cards that would eventually collapse, and that the US could be best served by remaining in isolation and sitting out the collapse.

The U.S. moved to re-establish diplomatic ties with the world's nations, but internally, the debate over America's future quickly escalated, and before serious steps could be made in diplomacy, America found itself in a full-scale civil war, with the expansionist, isolationist, and diplomatic factions fighting for control of the United States. The world observed the US civil war with varying degrees of concern, but ultimately took no action to interfere. They felt that the world was fine without America, and what happened there was of no concern to the global community.

This was a mistake. The Second Civil War raged out of control, eventually leading to the deployment of nuclear weapons, and the US became a nuclear wasteland. Far from being unaffected, the rest of the world suffered from the ensuing nuclear winter, and all the progress that humanity had made was swiftly erased.

The United States government sized up this situation, and an internal debate began; some suggested that the only way to reclaim its former glory would be for America to force its way back to the front of the world stage, while others suggested that perhaps the isolation of 50 years had contributed to a kind of peaceful stability, and that maybe the United States should leave well enough alone, and join in the peace and prosperity, in a more minor role rather than its former status as a superpower. A third group believed the current global situation was a house of cards that would eventually collapse, and that the US could be best served by remaining in isolation and sitting out the collapse.

The U.S. moved to re-establish diplomatic ties with the world's nations, but internally, the debate over America's future quickly escalated, and before serious steps could be made in diplomacy, America found itself in a full-scale civil war, with the expansionist, isolationist, and diplomatic factions fighting for control of the United States. The world observed the US civil war with varying degrees of concern, but ultimately took no action to interfere. They felt that the world was fine without America, and what happened there was of no concern to the global community.

This was a mistake. The Second Civil War raged out of control, eventually leading to the deployment of nuclear weapons, and the US became a nuclear wasteland. Far from being unaffected, the rest of the world suffered from the ensuing nuclear winter, and all the progress that humanity had made was swiftly erased.

The U.S. moved to re-establish diplomatic ties with the world's nations, but internally, the debate over America's future quickly escalated, and before serious steps could be made in diplomacy, America found itself in a full-scale civil war, with the expansionist, isolationist, and diplomatic factions fighting for control of the United States. The world observed the US civil war with varying degrees of concern, but ultimately took no action to interfere. They felt that the world was fine without America, and what happened there was of no concern to the global community.

This was a mistake. The Second Civil War raged out of control, eventually leading to the deployment of nuclear weapons, and the US became a nuclear wasteland. Far from being unaffected, the rest of the world suffered from the ensuing nuclear winter, and all the progress that humanity had made was swiftly erased.

So, it happened that even in isolation, America was once again able to disrupt the world and plunge it into darkness.
